trial_identification.studytitle: Arterial Blood Gas Sampling: 23G Versus 25G Needle - A Randomised Control Study to Compare Pain
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Arterial Blood Gas Needle Study: A Randomised Control Study Comparing 23 gauge Versus 25 gauge Needle Success & Pain Score
trial_identification.secondaryid: Arterial Blood Gas Sampling: 23G Versus 25G Needle - A Randomised Control Study to Compare Pain

conditions.healthcondition: Pain in arterial blood gas sampling
Complications related to arterial blood gas sampling

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Research that is not of generic health relevance and not applicable to specific health categories listed above

interventions.interventions: Taking small amount of blood (0.5ml) from the radial artery at the wrist with a thicker 23G needle.
interventions.comparator: Taking small amount of blood (0.5ml) from the radial artery at the wrist with a thinner 25G needle.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The degree of pain experienced by patients during an arterial blood gas puncture with different gauge needles measured on a 10cm visual analogue scale assessed after each puncture.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The success rates & complications assessed once during an arterial blood gas puncture with different gauge needles. Procedural difficulty measured on a 10cm visual analogue scale.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All patients presenting to the emergency department who need to undergo arterial blood gas analysis as part of their diagnostic work up will be considered candidates for the study provided they do not fulfil the absolute exclusion criteria.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Patients with altered mental/cognitive/medical state either acute or chronic deemed not able to convey pain score accurately. 2. Unwell patients who require urgent medical intervention which precludes informed consent such as Category 1 patients.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose ot the study is compare two of the commonly used needles in arterial blood gas taking and to determine the level of pain/success rate & complications. Whilst the smaller needle may be theoritically less painful, there is uncertainty whether it is more difficult to perform leading to lower success rates & complications.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Sydney West Area Health Service Human Research Ethics Committee

contact.title: Dr
